Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The new Canon PowerShot G1 X - commonly shortened to Canon G1 X, or even Canon G1X - occupies the top spot in Canon's prestigious G-series compact camera range, offering a truly impressive array of high-end features.
Launched at CES earlier this year, the new digital camera is aimed at advanced photographers in search of a high-quality, take-anywhere primary camera and/or backup for their DSLR.
To that end, the Canon G1 X is packed with advanced technologies designed to deliver the very best performance.
It may not be the compact system camera (CSC) that everyone was expecting to see from Canon, nor is it a direct replacement for the highly popular Canon PowerShot G12 - rather, it's something in between.
As such, it's difficult to slot the Canon G1 X into any ... one particular category and so - as Canon is keen to point out - it's just as tricky to determine natural rivals for this new camera.
The Canon PowerShot G1 X's specifications make for very impressive reading. It boasts a 14.3MP CMOS sensor that's almost the same size as an EOS DSLR's, sporting a pixel structure and size that's equivalent to that on the entry-level Canon EOS 600D's CMOS device.
The latest generation Digic 5 image processor drives this camera's performance and promises to deliver richly-detailed shots with well-controlled noise, while the Canon G1X's fast, 4x optical image stabilisation (IS) zoom lens incorporates a new design using Ultra High Refractive Index Aspherical (UA) elements for supreme image quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: DCRP Review: Canon PowerShot G1 X
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent photo quality, with low noise until highest ISOs; Solid build quality, with lots of dials and direct buttons; Optical image stabilization; Super high resolution 3-inch rotating LCD display; Optical viewfinder is always a nice touch; Full manual controls, including RAW support; Smart Auto mode picks a scene mode (and the proper IS setting) for you; Tons of scene modes and Creative Filters; Dynamic range correction and HDR features improve image contrast; Customizable button, menu, and spots on mode dial; Handy electronic level; Built-in neutral density filter; Redeye not an issue -- if it does become one, a removal tool is available in playback mode; Records Full HD (1080/24p) video with stereo sound, use of optical zoom; Very expandable, with optional external flash, lens h ... ood and filters, underwater housing, and wired remote
Cons: Expensive; Likes to clip highlights; Lens on the slow side at telephoto end; AF performance needs improvement; Long minimum focus distances mean frequent switching between normal and macro AF when subjects are close; Design annoyances: bulky body, lens visible through viewfinder, can't access memory card slot when using tripod; Movies are a bit choppy due to 24 fps frame rate -- no manual controls available; Unremarkable burst mode; Below average battery life; Full manual on CD-ROM
if you've got $800 burning a hole in your pocket and want a semi-compact camera with D-SLR image quality, then look no further than the Canon PowerShot G1 X. It's not for action photography (due to its sluggish focusing and burst modes) nor is it great for close-ups, but for virtually every other situation, the G1 X delivers. I'm hopeful that Canon's next large sensor camera will have a faster lens, snappier performance, and improved battery life, but for now, the G1 X is easily good enough for me to recommend. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The biggest attraction with the G1X is naturally the larger sensor and the fact that it's a CMOS sensor, as opposed to the usual CCD found in point-and-shoots. This holds out the promise of noticeably improved image quality, and the possibility a photographer can use all the camera's features, rather than having to work around its shortcomings. A quick test of a gray, white and black subject at the main ISO speeds, with high noise reduction on, shows the sensor to produce greatly reduced noise, especially in the high- to very-high range. Where previous point-and-shoots would begin exhibiting noise as low as ISO 200, the G1X holds up remarkably well even at the higher ISOs, and this bodes well for improved image quality, as well as for low-light shooting. Before talking good and bad point ... s, let's say what this camera is NOT. It's not an SLR in disguise, nor is it intended as an SLR replacement. So comparing its performance to an SLR, and especially complaining about that, seems wrongheaded. But it CAN and should be compared with previously-released point-and-shoots, representing as it does a step forward in that category. Having said that, here are the things I like about the camera: 1. The large, flip-out LCD view screen; Canon seems to be listening to customers who find this a huge bonus and it's a good thing to continue. 2. Anyone notice that the aperture closes down to F-16 -- two stops more than previous Powershots, including the G-12? This gives the photographer more flexibility with both exposure and Depth of Field. Very nice to have! 3. The shutter speed and F-stop settings are controlled with separate wheels -- more like a pro camera -- rather than one toggle switch. This allows you to work faster when adjusting exposure. 4. The Exposure Compensation dial is on an always-ready dial with a very sure grip -- no need to access a menu. And here are the things I dislike: 1. The position of -- and lack of protection for -- the video-engage button makes it too easy to accidentally trigger the start of a video. I've done this several times and it wastes space on the memory card. AND it's annoying for someone who doesn't use a still digital camera to shoot videos. 2. The standard lens cap setup -- with the cap tethered to the neck strap -- is a clunky throwback to previous G-series cameras. The cap is necessary for lens protection but swings around awkwardly. Better to remove it and consider a UV filter and filter adapter to protect the lens, since there are no blades to do that automatically. A filter setup could be considered a plus, actually, and more like a pro setup, but then there's the price tag for the adapter plus the filter. 3. I do like the popup flash, but the flash menus need simplification. Too hard to sort through them, as is true of other Powershots. 4. Like many of its predecessors, the macro function on the G1X is disappointing. You can really only get close enough for true macros with the lens at a wide focal length, and than may not give the desired framing or Depth of Field. Thus, if you want to shoot close-ups, this is not really the camera of choice. And that's too bad. Overall, though, there's more to like about this camera than to dislike, and it does represent a groundbreaking step toward improved cameras for people who want decent quality digital shots, say, on vacations, but are loathe to lug around a heavy SLR and several lenses. I can place myself in that category and I'm looking forward to what the G1x can do on my next vacation come this June. expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: Use of Adobe Photoshop CS5 RAW with G1 X
Item.Review: Latest Adobe Camera Raw 6.7 for Photoshop CS5(Adobe Labs - Candidate Release) as of March 5, 2012 will take care of converting the RAW files taken on the G1X Camera. Battery life is very very poor, especially with use of LCD, and this is evident in the lack of available Canon NB-10L Batteries on the market as of today. Other G1X owners have probably had to purchase 1 or 2 spare batteries for t ... heir G1X camera; not a bad idea but the availability is lacking even direct from Canon USA which makes me wonder if this camera is going to survive. Why no printed user manual provided with the camera was a surprise and mystery to me. Very cheap of Canon not to provide a printed user manual with this camera which they have done in the past. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: love this little camera. Honestly I hate point & shoots. but this little guy has some serious potentual. First off IQ especially with flash is top notch. And that's just the pop up flash!! menu is intuitive comming from a 7D and currently using a 5Dmk3. AF is terrible compared to DSLR's, incretibly slow. set center AF point and optical zoom instead of using digital zoom. helps get best IQ and with composition. leave AF assist beam on. test 430 ex ii and works great. lens is sharp through entire range. remember to hold it steady. don't just rely on stabilizer. was shocked to see ISO 1600 being geat, 3200 being good (and 6400 usable is printing 5x7). this is all with out shooting raw and not applying any noise reduction software. Video quality is stunningly good!, surprising 1hr 1080p ... with 16gb card. didn't see limit, ( maybe because this is a point & shoot ). read audio is bad, didn't test. Hated handling nex 5n, almost fell out of my hands just trying to pick it up. I have American large hands. This is the body for Professional Photographers Point and shoot with normal sized hands wanting to use full manual. love the articulating screen. incredibly useful. this camera feels small in my hands, but with good grip and ergonomics for its size. it is not big just a tad bit heavy. Price could be lower, but there's nothing that handles this good with this iQ period!!! the Nex has better IQ 15% better but seriously bad ergonomics and not for a Professsional wanting to shoot in full manual and no hot shoe! I chose the 5Dmk3 because it's by far a better all around body then the D800, this is a much better all around point and shoot then the nex 5n. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm probably exactly the guy Canon had in mind when they dreamed up the Powershot G1X: I do most of my seriousl shooting with a DSLR, but wanted a much smaller, high-quality camera that I could take anywhere, or use as a backup for my DSLR. The G1X shoots raw files, so whatever I take is publishable, so I lose nothing in that regard. Its high-quality optics and extra large CMOS sensor give me crisp images that can be cropped hard if needed, but still retain incredible sharpness. In my experience, color rendition is a bit on the cool side, but white balance is adjustable. The lens has an 28- to 112mm zoom range (35mm equivalent) plus a limited macro range (at closest focus tele macro, you can almost fill the frame with an 8 1/2 by 11 inch page; at wide, you can more than fill the frame with ... the same page). In other words, the camera is set up to do all the basics extremely well; if you want something with extra telephoto or macro capability, buy something else (but lose the advantages of the extra large chip). I've read complaints about the optical viewfinder. While it's true that I use the LCD for composed shots, the optical viewfinder works fine (and zooms right along with the lens) for grab shots of people and animals. The menus are well-organized, intuitive, and have on-screen help that makes it quickly apparent what each item does (if you can't figure it out yourself). The camera is made like a fine Swiss watch???very precise and solid. My only complaint is that when the electronic level is calibrated to be perfectly horizontal in the landscape (horizontal) position, it's off in the vertical. When I calibrate it for vertical, it throws off horizontal leveling. The G1X can be customized lots of ways???it takes a 240-page pdf file to elaborate on all the possibilities???but you'll soon have it set up for the way that best suits your shooting style. Since I'm a still photographer, I don't use or care about the camera's video abilities, so you'll have to read different reviews that cover that. This camera is perfect for me. My advice is to carefully read about its feature set to decide whether it's for you. What it promises, it delivers, and then some. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Image Quality is AMAZING
Cons: Price, weight, MACRO, Zoom
First let me say.... I am one of those "horrible" people who, when new camera technology comes out, will sell my old equipment to upgrade because I can't resist the newness. That being said - I previously owned the G12... which is an AMAZING little camera. I love it. but the allure of the bigger sensor and HD video (along with a few other minor details) wooed me into purchasing the G1X. (Also - another side note - I am a professional photographer who wanted a camera that I could pack around when I didn't want to carry my "big guns". And the Canon G Series is the BEST way to go - if you are in the same boat. It is NOT a DSLR... so please do not even try to compare it to a DSLR. It is what it is.... an outstanding ... "carry around" camera when you don't want to pack the DSLR).
So here is a basic overview of what I think of the G1X - and especially comparing it to the G12.
VIDEO: Outstanding improvement. If video is important to you - then you might consider the G1X. The video is excellent quality and I am more than pleased with it. Sound is great and IQ is great. I have one little complaint - and that is - that the zoom in video mode is painfullly slooooowwww. Other than that - it's great.
MACRO: Okay... so here is my biggest complaint. If you are serious (or even interested in) shooting in Macro mode... this is NOT the camera for you. Turn around and purchase the G12. (IT does a good job with Macro). There is NO macro capability and I think that it's even a bit of a joke that "macro" even shows up when you get close to something. It WILL NOT focus on what you want it to focus on. Canon... You NEED to fix the Macro on the G Series. End of story.
IQ: Well - I think I already wrapped this one up. Image Quality - especially in low ligh (I do not - ever - shoot with flash. So low light capability is a MAJOR deal for me) is absolutely amazing for a point-and-shoot camera.... and I gues that's all I can really say about that.
Even though I don't shoot in "Auto" mode.... ( ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Disappointed is How I Would Put It. . .
Item.Review: I've been leaving my DSLR at home on vacations and taking my point and shoot taking jpeg images with fair results. But I would like to get RAW files and improved image quality and size. Along comes the G1 X. Love the idea of RAW and all the manual features up front and easy to access without menus. After reading early reviews, I decided this camera has most of the features I am looking for: articulated LCD, RAW files, rangefinder viewer, external manual controls, electronic level and a hot shoe. I thought I understood it was bigger than a point and shoot, but hey, I have big pockets just not deep ones. Although you might think I have deep pockets for what this camera costs so for what his gem costs. If it hadn't taken me so long to get this camera on the road to really put it to t ... he test as a vacation camera, I would return it. One of the first things I discovered is how annoying the lens cap tether is. It takes you free hand to keep the lens cap from flopping around while you try to frame up a shot or change from horizontal to vertical. The other very annoying thing is the instant video button placed right next to the the thumb rest. It didn't take long to discover that the camera loves to shoot wild video of the ground, sky, and blurred landscapes. I wasted a lot of battery power and card space accidentally pressing the little red record button. You think the engineers would have put a menu option for deactivating this little red annoyance for those of us who have big fat thumbs and don't spend a lot of time shooting video we'll never use. Maybe a a disable feature can be included in any new firmware upgrades. The macro feature is not happening with this camera. The larger sensor is a trade off I guess for being able to close focus. I could use my 58mm screw on close-up lenses if Canon every gets the filter adapter available. While the 28mm eq. wide angle is passible, I miss the longer telephoto of my DSLR or even on my PNS. Not because of magnification, but for limiting the angle of view. So I guess I'm stuck. After all the bad reviews I've seen here, it will be hard to sell this camera for anything but a big loss. I'll buy a neck strap and put it around my neck on the next vacation to keep from stretching out my pocket and make room for my PNS back up camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: My new Stealth 24p HD wonder cam
Item.Review: So far, so great! Photo's look really superb. Even DOF suprisingly good bokeh but you have to zoom the lens all the way out with the subject in focus up close. Amazing. But I bought this point and shoot for it's video capture capabilities. The only thing I DON'T like is that (like on SLR) you have an actual 24,30,50,60 locked in screen that you lock in what setting you want. This doesn't have that. Just say's when you are in HD you are in 24p and when in SD you are 30p. kinda lame if you ask me. In my first initial video tests I notice some rolling shutter problems. But the image itself? unreal. Great lens, great DIGIC 5 (new look)...which im really liking. The point and shoot options on this camera are so fun. I wish I had these goofball options on my 5D. This camera is such a STEALTH ind ... y film cam. No one will think you are shooting 24p HD...in let's say a STADIUM for a crowd scene. haha. I wish the zoom was a little farther. I am very impressed with the W I D E on this puppy. totally great as is. Although it has built in ND filters (which is cool). I have ordered the filter adapter and ND filters. I will definatly use this on corporate ENG gigs as well. Thank you B&H for your customer service rep's telling me about this camera. Bang for the BUCK superb and great EMERGENCY back up for DSLR filming or EXTRA cam on music video, ENG, DOCU or even stealth shot on Indy feature with the 24p. So far, loving this puppy. (way better than my g11 for photos and as good as my 7D, 5D with nice glass photo's = ) expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have been waiting for a high quality pocket camera with good manual control for a couple years, Canon G1X is the right one. Here is the pros and cons: Pro: - Sensor size. I simply do not believe in nail size sensors. - Size and weight: It fits in my hand, and feel good for the weight when taking pictures at low speed. - ISO: Very good at 1600 - Silent on movie mode Cons - Slow focus. I have not found manual focus, will do more research. - Macro is a joke. - OVF is useless. Others - White balance is about average

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Don't pay attention to bad-mouth reviews
Item.Review: Too many reviews treat this camera as one to replace a Canon 7D or Canon 5D, and, therefore, complain about its shortcomings relative to those cameras. That's just dead wrong. That is not what this camera is about. I use a camera for scenic views in places like National Parks, and to record memories of interiors of museum, castles, art galleries, Bhutanese temples, Papua New Guinea long houses, etc. during my travels to the far corners of the earth. It is perfect for those activities. It has a huge sensor with pixel density roughly the same as that of the Canon 7D, and a high performance Digic 5 processor. It has an excellent stabilized lens. It has an excellent artuclated screen. It has a poor view finder. It takes brilliant pictures in outdoor settings. It takes totally usable pi ... ctures in the dimmest of lighting at ISO settings up to 3200, and quite acceptable pictures even up to ISO 12,800. It is the perfect camera for those environments. It takes HD video. The lens is somewhat slow, but its high ISO capability makes that not an issue. It is bigger than most compacts. I need to use hiking sticks to walk, so I use a belt attached device that holds the camera comfortably in a locked state, and releases rapidly for use. Its weight is totally tolerable for this transport method. I will use it where lugging my Canon 7D is just too taxing. It uses a contrast focusing technique that is not the fastest, but focuses perfectly for my uses. If you are into sports photography, or photography of any rapidly moving objects that you want to focus on qickly, and hold the focus, this is definitely not the camera for you. If you are into macro photography it is also not the camera for you. It has poor close focusing capability. It has a fixed 4x zoom lens, 28 to 112, so it is not great where large zooms are required. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Impressive features in a small package
Item.Review: Even though this camera offers many advanced features, its use is intuitive. I was able to take full advantage of this fantastic camera with minimal reading of the well-written manual. Pros: Very good low light use Full Automatic mode can be use 95% of the time. The high resolution allows for extreme cropping, without losing quality. Response time, from power on to first photo is very fast. Comparable to most DSLR cameras, both in quality and price. This camera offers too much to be considered a point and shoot. Cons: Minimal optical zoom(but offset by high resolution). Relatively heavy for a point and shoot. Video quality is just ok.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: The Almost Perfect Grab and Go Camera
Item.Review: I have been using this camera for about six weeks and I find it is excellent as a grab and go camera. Wherever I'm going and whatever I'm doing, this camera has been great for taking along for any unplanned photo op that comes up. While not tiny like a point and shoot, it is small, compact and light and easy to carry along in a small shoulder bag, backpack, satchel, etc. It is well balanced and the size is just right for easy handling. Image quality has been excellent with sharp pictures across focal and aperture ranges. I have mostly been shooting in Raw, but JPEGS have also been quite good. The external controls and menu system make it easy to take full control of image making. The G1X has a quality look and feel to it. The fully articulating LCD is a beauty and very useful for ... all kinds of creative shots. The camera does have a few weak points. I miss the excellent macro of my old G11, but I can manage without it. The simple optical viewfinder is pathetic, and it seems a good EVF should be possible and included at this price given what other manufacturers are producing. Shutter responsiveness is also rather slow and is not competitive with CSC offerings. Overall, I really like the G1X for its simple all in one portability and great image quality. However, improvements I would like to see would be the inclusion of an EVF with info display, quicker focus and shutter response, and a 24mm focal length at the wide end. That would make it a truly perfect grab and go camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Superb step-up from Point and Shoot
Item.Review: The fold-out LCD Screen is very bright, clear, and so very convenient for shooting at odd angles. The size, shape, and weight are great for someone who prefers a smaller, lighter camera with great capability. This is a fantastic find either as a back-up for SLR, or as an almost-SLR. Image quality and ability to shoot in lower lighting conditions is superb. On the not so upside, the Auto Focus in Macro mode is not as easy to use as my PowerShot S50, surprisingly. At least, the manual focus is easier. Occasionally hitting the Macro focus button and have to re-select. On the more fussy end of my nitpicks: I had read that the front dial and shortcut buttons were user-assignable, but I'm rather disappointed with the selections. If this is important to you, download the User Guide from Ca ... non and make certain that you read up. Wish the Zoom was a bit higher, but honestly, it's quite good. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This camera is solidly built. The larger sensor enables low noise at much higher iso settings than typical point and shoot cameras. Although it will not fit in a shirt pocket it will fit comfortably in a large jacket pocket. The only annoying feature is the video record button sits very close to where you would normally rest your thumb. This causes inadvertent video recording. Canon needs to update it's software to deactivate the video record button.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I replaced a G12 with the G1X on Friday. I've taken about 100 comparison photos of a scene similar to my test shots of the G12. Different weather conditions but so far the images are well saturated, clean and seem to have much more shadow detail. It is bigger compared to the G12, mostly in thickness. The lens is really huge and closed sticks out a half inch. The lens cap is very good since it doesn't have a built in cover. It is very easy to handle. The body seems to be much better thought out as though they hired a Nikon guy to give them ergonomic pointers. The dedicated movie button is really handy and the controls are similar to G series cameras. The sound is bad, bad, bad. Really bad and there isn't a way to add an external mic. Lots of zoom noise from the lens. BIG DISAPPOINTMENT! ... However, the 24p setting gives a nice MOV video file which shouldn't be compared to a true HD camera but is easy to edit. RAW is not currently supported in Photoshop or ACDSee Pro. Zoom Browser is the only way to view the files. The CR2 vs. JPG thumbs seem to be very close in tonality and luminosity. Flash coverage seems about equal to the G12 although detail is better and noise is lower. I used it in the WP-DC44 underwater housing which is much bigger than the WP-DC34 for the G12. Buy a WW-DC1 Weight Set if you don't already own one. This camera will be difficult to keep submerged without ballast. Flash coverage with the new housing is better than it was with the G12 largely because the flash has an attached diffuser tunnel that focuses more light were you need it. Bottom Line: if you are used to the G10-G12 series, you will start running with this right out of the box. The files are huge compared to those (about 11-14 meg) when shooting at highest resolution. One cool feature is variable aspect ratio imaging. I tend to use the 24x36 aspect to keep my full frame and pocket camera (ha! definitely won't fit in your pocket!) images similar. You will probably like this camera a lot after you get used to the size. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: OK, here's the deal with this camera. I shoot MMA Fighters full-time for a magazine. The G1X is my temporary backup camera 'til I get the Canon 1D X. My main camera is the 5D Mark II which will turn into my backup camera. I sold my old 5D to get the G1X. Now your probably saying What are you doing using a point-and-shoot for a backup camera? I've found the image quality is on par with my old 5D and maybe a little better than the Canon 7D. It's got great high ISO rendering. I always wanted a compact camera for personal use and for times when I don't want to carry around my heavy camera bag. Like times when I go mountain biking. There is no other compact camera I could live with as far as image quality until this one. My biggest complaint is that it's so small that I don't have a very big ar ... ea to put my right thumb when holding the camera. Just takes a little getting used to. I love how the rear viewing screen flips out and flips around. This is my seventh Canon camera with my first back in 1985. The first G1X I ordered had a spot on the sensor, so I returned it to B and H and they sent out the replacement. I've never had to send a camera back and the replacement I received seems to be just fine. So one faulty camera out of seven is not too bad. I bought the Lowepro 60 AW camera bag which fits like it was made for this camera. I can just strap this bag to my camelback shoulder strap and go mountain biking. When I want to take a shot, it's right there. I wouldn't want to use this camera as my permanent backup camera, but I believe I could get the job done with this camera if my 5D Mark II died on me during a photo shoot . . . which has never happened. Even when I get my permanent backup camera, this G1X is always going to be with me because a compact camera that delivers a quality RAW image is awesome! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I hate being without a camera, but the bulk and weight of my DSLR is a bit much when not working. Not eager to surrender the benefits of shooting raw images, point & shoots didn't made the grade, until I discovered the G1X. And it gives me HD video! It never leaves my side, and my wife is starting to get jealous.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G1 X 14.3 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I returned my camera after trying it out for 10 days. The screen was difficult to see in daylight, the viewer is small and useless and the plastic parts are just not solid. The photographs were good but the macro feature was bad. For the money its not worth it. As a pro I thought this might be a great walk around light camera but I am now going with the another brand. Canon could have put a lot more work into this one and I'm going to get the lumix.
